title: Watchmen episode 2 questions: Is Will Reeves really Doctor Manhattan?
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

**Warning spoilers for Watchmen episode two ahead!**

Watchmen just dropped its latest episode Martial Feats of Comanche Horsemanship and we’re still coming to terms with what we’ve just watched.

Despite almost losing main character Detective Angela Abar (Regina Kings) thanks to a coordinated attack on all police in their houses on Christmas eve, the majority of the installment saw the vigilante try and gain information on Will Reeves (Louis Gossett Jr).

This brings us nicely to our first question…

Is Will Reeves actually Doctor Manhattan like he says he is?

Advertisement

Advertisement

The installment kicked off with the mysterious Will confessing to Angela that he is the infamous Doctor Manhattan and that he killed Cheif Judd Crawafuord (Don Johnson).

Is Will really Doctor Manhattan? (Picture: HBO)

‘I can manipulate material with my mind,’ Will admitted. ‘Maybe I’m Doctor Manhattan.’

Pushing his case further, Will continued: ‘He can make copies of himself, he can be in two places at the same time, he can grow 200ft tall, change the colour of my skin.’

Angela doubted that Will was being truthful over her colleague’s death, what with him being 105-years-old and wheelchair-bound and so were we… to begin with.

Will continued to talk in riddles as the episode progressed, but in the closing scenes when Angela arrested him and went to take him into the station, something super weird happened.

As the Will was left alone in the car, for literally a split second, a giant magnet appeared, picking up the vehicle and flying it away.

Immediately after he disappeared, a letter fell from the sky, reading: ‘Watch over this boy.’

Is Will really Doctor Manhattan after all?

Why is Adrian Veidt cloning his servants?

We had a lot of questions when we first met Adrian Veidt (Jeremy Irons) last week and it seems they’re just going to keep on coming.

We have questions… (Picture: HBO)

This time around we saw the wealthy mad scientist order his servants to perform a play after he’d celebrated another anniversary by being presented with another cake.

Advertisement

The performance ended with one of Adrian’s subjects, John, being burnt to a crisp after being torched in a chamber, but all seemed okay in the end as he reappeared as ‘Doctor Manhattan’.

‘I am both John and not John,’ the cloned John said as he arrived on stage completely nude and painted blue.

‘I am the past, present, and the future all at once. Boundless omniscient incarnate swirling in the luminous plasma of a newborn star.’

Why’s Adrian cloning his subjects and how is this going to tie in with the main story?

Watchmen is available to stream on HBO in the US and Sky Atlantic and NOW TV in the UK.
